1.text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, You are permitted to speak for yourself. Then Paul stretched forth the hand, and answered for himself:

2.text: I think myself happy, king Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before you touching all the things whereof I am accused of the Jews:

3.text: Especially because I know you to be expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews: why I beseech you to hear me patiently.

4.text: My manner of life from my youth, which was at the first among my own nation at Jerusalem, know all the Jews;

5.text: Which knew me from the beginning, if they would testify, that after the most strait sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.

6.text: And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God, to our fathers:

7.text: To which promise our twelve tribes, instantly serving God day and night, hope to come. For which hopeâ€™s sake, king Agrippa, I am accused of the Jews.

8.text: Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead?

9.text: I truly thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.

10.text: Which thing I also did in Jerusalem: and many of the saints did I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against them.

11.text: And I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compelled them to blaspheme; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted them even to strange cities.

12.text: Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,

13.text: At midday, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and them which journeyed with me.

14.text: And when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking to me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecute you me? it is hard for you to kick against the pricks.

15.text: And I said, Who are you, Lord? And he said, I am Jesus whom you persecute.

16.text: But rise, and stand on your feet: for I have appeared to you for this purpose, to make you a minister and a witness both of these things which you have seen, and of those things in the which I will appear to you;

17.text: Delivering you from the people, and from the Gentiles, to whom now I send you,

18.text: To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me.

19.text: Whereupon, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision:

20.text: But showed first to them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the coasts of Judaea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works meet for repentance.

21.text: For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple, and went about to kill me.

22.text: Having therefore obtained help of God, I continue to this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying none other things than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come:

23.text: That Christ should suffer, and that he should be the first that should rise from the dead, and should show light to the people, and to the Gentiles.

24.text: And as he thus spoke for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, you are beside yourself; much learning does make you mad.

25.text: But he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus; but speak forth the words of truth and soberness.

26.text: For the king knows of these things, before whom also I speak freely: for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him; for this thing was not done in a corner.

27.text: King Agrippa, believe you the prophets? I know that you believe.

28.text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, Almost you persuade me to be a Christian.

29.text: And Paul said, I would to God, that not only you, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.

30.text: And when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them:

31.text: And when they were gone aside, they talked between themselves, saying, This man does nothing worthy of death or of bonds.

32.text: Then said Agrippa to Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed to Caesar.
